title: Bank account levied to pay a judgment- can they levy me again? If so, how soon? Or will levy just "sit there" until fully paid?
question: I have a judgmnet of $6215.00 against me. Creditor levied my bank account and got $511.00 I didn't know what was going on until it was too late to file any exemption forms.
answers:
Only the amount in the account on the date the writ of attachment is served can be turned over to the creditor.

To levy the same account again, the creditor would need to apply for a new writ and pay the sheriff a new fee to re-serve the new writ of attachment.

(Multiple levies could be a concern with someone who has direct deposit and an HR department that is slow to process direct deposit account changes or cancellations.)

I am not aware of any mandatory "waiting period" in between levies on the same account. But, as a practical matter, the judgment creditor has to complete new levy paperwork showing updated amounts owed after the first levy was completed.

This could take 15 days since that is how long it takes for the money from the first levy to be turned over to the judgment creditor.

Authority for the above:
California CCP 488.455 (b) The attachment lien that arises upon service of a writ of
attachment and notice of attachment reaches only amounts in a deposit
account at the time of service on the financial institution,
including the amount of any deposit not yet finally collected, unless
the deposit is returned unpaid to the financial institution.

I respectfully disagree with my colleagues. The writ of execution has a finite "life" of 180 days. However, each bank account levy must be requested by the creditor and a fee must be paid to the sheriff to re-deliver the writ to the bank. Whatever is in your bank account on the date the sheriff re-delivers the writ is what the bank is required to pay to the sheriff. For example, if the sheriff delivers the writ to the bank on January 5 and you have $50 in the account, that is what the sheriff gets. If you deposit $10,000 on January 6, the bank pays nothing to the sheriff. This works differently for a wage garnishment. In the event the sheriff delivers the writ to your employer, up to 25% of your net wages can be withheld each payday. One delivery, many withholdings. To sum up, no new funds are "scooped up" from your bank account as a result of one writ delivery by the sheriff. A Chapter 7 BK filed within 90 days of a bank levy permits you to recover amounts levied from you for any amounts if you can exempt them when you file the BK. BK is not a DIY project and you should find/consult/hire an Avvo lawyer by clicking on the tab "Find a Lawyer". Many of us give free consultations. Hope this clarified your situation.

Yes, the levy will remain until fully satisfied. BUT, you should have received a copy of the notice of levy along with a blank claim of exemption form with instructions. If you have valid grounds to claim an exemption in some or all of the funds in the account, it is not too late to complete the claim of exemption form and serve it on the levying officer (as shown on the notice of levy).

Serving the exemption claim won't always stop more money from being levied, but it will cause the levying officer to hold the funds, and not send them to the creditor, until there has been a hearing on your exemption claim. If you succeed in your exemption claim, the funds will be returned to you.

Also if you file a bankruptcy, all future levies will be stayed and if your bk is filed within 90 days of the levy you can possibly recover those funds already levied.

You should consult with a local bankruptcy attorney to review all the facts of your situation and your options. Most will offer a free initial consultation.
Existing levy should remain in effect until satisfied--no new levy.

Yes, the levy will stay in effect and scoop up any funds deposited into that account. The creditor will seek to find anywhere that you may have funds. additionally, if you are employed, the creditor may seek a garnishment of your wages. Consult a bankruptcy attorney in your area to see what options you have available. Good luck!
The levy will indeed stay in effect--scooping up any available funds--until it's satisfied.
